keyTakeAways: A Slovak court convicted 72-year-old poet Juraj Cintula of a 'terror attack' for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico on May 15, 2024.
The court sentenced Cintula to 21 years in prison, citing political motivation and an intent to disrupt government functionality.
Cintula claimed his actions were driven by 'moral despair' and a protest against Fico's government decisions, such as halting aid to Ukraine.
Fico has repeatedly accused liberal opposition and media of fueling the attack, without providing evidence, and has strengthened ties with Russia and adopted authoritarian policies.
The incident has intensified political divisions in Slovakia and raised concerns about democratic backsliding and state violence.
Cintula described Fico as 'drunk with power' and said his actions reflected widespread public frustration over corruption and power abuse.
Cintula’s lawyer stated he would likely appeal the verdict, indicating ongoing legal and political controversy.
Slovakia’s parliament recently passed a constitutional amendment limiting same-sex couple rights and asserting national law over EU law, further polarizing the country.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has convicted poet Juraj Cintula of a 'terror attack' for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico on May 15, 2024, sentencing him to 21 years in prison. Cintula, from Levice, claimed he acted out of 'moral despair' and protest against Fico’s government decisions, including halting aid to Ukraine. The incident has deepened political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico accusing the opposition and media of inciting violence while pushing a more authoritarian and pro-Russian stance, and criticizing EU policies. The case has sparked national debate over political extremism, government accountability, and democratic erosion, especially in light of recent constitutional changes limiting same-sex rights and asserting national law over EU law.
title: Slovak court sentences poet that shot PM to 21 years for ‘terror attack’
